headline.main: Making Books; No Rush to Ride Viagra Coattails

docs.abstract: Martin Arnold's column on lack of interest among publishers in producing a book on Viagra, the pill for male impotence, despite public's fascination (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: First the pill, then the book. Viagra, taking everyone through all the spheres of promise. For men the dream of erectile function. For a few book publishers, the hope of excitation of a different sort. The perception is that in book publishing there is the tendency to jump on every hot scientific, semi-scientific or even pseudo-scientific breakthough and follow up with a book as quickly as possible. Now it's supposed to be Viagra infatuation. But there is only one Viagra book in the stores, and just two more are known to be on the way, although there are more agent and writer proposals circulating. So the pill that is going to make the ground tremble thus far has not caused great vibration among publishers.
docs.snippet: First the pill, then the book. Viagra, taking everyone through all the spheres of promise. For men the dream of erectile function. For a few book publishers, the hope of excitation of a different sort.    The perception is that in book publishing...

docs.abstract: Purdue University sociologist Kenneth Ferraro finds that church-going Americans apparently weigh more than their less religious neighbors; finds strong correlations between body weight and religious membership; says findings may reflect range of causes, including acceptance of heavy people in church; another explanation is tendency of churches to celebrate with lots of food; Michigan, Mississippi and Indiana have most overweight people and higher rates of religious affiliation; both rates are lowest in Massachusetts, Hawaii and Colorado; Baptists tend to be heaviest, and Jews, Muslims and Buddhists are least often overweight (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Religious, church-going Americans apparently weigh more than their less religious neighbors, even though they follow many healthy routines, Prof. Kenneth Ferraro of Purdue University has found.. Dr. Ferraro, a sociologist, said he found strong correlations between body weight and religious membership. He said the findings may reflect a range of causes, including acceptance of heavy people in churches.
